thread.title: New York can be the land of the free if you're looking in the right places
thread.title_full: New York can be the land of the free if you're looking in the right places - Mirror Online

author: By Mirror.co.uk
title: New York can be the land of the free if you're looking in the right places
text:
From my vantage point at the Top of the Rock looking towards Central Park, I checked out 432 Park Avenue as it cast a thin shadow over New York below.
The view from the Rockefeller Center observation deck was just as breathtaking as the £11million an apartment in the tallest residential tower in the western hemisphere will set you back.
But you don’t need to have big bucks to enjoy a break in the Big Apple – there are plenty of things to do which won’t cost a dime.
For starters, the sheer thrill of just being in New York is priceless – it’s like being on a giant film set. The city is an attraction in itself and days can be lost wandering around it.
Grand Central Terminal hardly feels like a train station – more of a spectacular stage, home to the emotional finale of Crocodile Dundee (or Carlito’s Way, if you prefer cooler films).
High Line: Running from Manhattan’s Meat Packing district
The city is a lot greener than you would expect, and the many beautiful parks are a great place to hang out and people-watch for free.
I grabbed a huge Cuban sandwich from a deli near the New York Public Library, and enjoyed it in Bryant Park before I took advantage of the free chess and Jenga tables.
Of all the things you can do without spending a cent, the wonderful High Line trumps most.
Running from Manhattan’s Meat Packing district, the disused raised railroad has had a $100million transformation into a “park in the sky”. A sunset stroll along its mile-and-a-half length provided perfect views up and down the city’s straight streets.
A city guide is highly recommended, especially with Ellen Baird, from Free Tours on Foot, which cost me nothing.
The park is not far from Roger Smith, a boutique art hotel which is about as traditional as you will get for £130 a night in Manhattan. For something a bit more modern, Yotel is a perfect base to explore the city – and you’re just a subway ride from the rest of New York.
Film set: Grand Central Station
Unlimited travel for a week costs just $30 (£19) – taking you up to the Bronx, all the way to Staten Island and the furthest corners of Brooklyn.
While the well-heeled head out to Long Island and the Hamptons, I was more than happy to make the hour’s journey south-east to Coney Island. It’s wonderfully kitsch and trash – think Blackpool USA.
In between Manhattan and the Brooklyn seafront is the appropriately named “other” Fifth Avenue in Park Slope.
The antithesis of its expensive sister in the Upper East Side, it is filled with boutique stores and interesting restaurants. Try La Villa for a perfect slice of real New York pizza. Other cheap but authentic treats came courtesy of Paul’s Da Burger Joint in the East Village and Luncheonette off Lexington for bacon and pancakes in syrup.
As a first timer, I did barely enough to dent New York’s surface, but still came home needing a week-long sleep to recuperate. And I managed to do this without bankrupting myself.
New York's top freebies The Museum of Modern Art is free on Fridays between 4pm and 8pm. moma.org Take the Staten Island Ferry. It’s a nice getaway, especially the botanical gardens. visitstatenisland.com Catch it at the right time and the boat to Governors Island is free – or as cheap as £1.50. govisland.com
Get a bike for free from 10am to noon. blazing saddles.com/new-york Go on The High Line tour with Ellen Baird. freetoursbyfoot.com Check out BRIC in Brooklyn, which show- cases local talent and events, many free. bricartsmedia.org For a full list of free Big Apple attractions go to nycgo.com/free
Where to stay Rooms at yotel from $149 (£95) per night. yotel.com
Roger Smith Hotel in the heart of Midtown has rooms from $200 (£130) per night. rogersmith.com
Getting there Thomas Cook Airlines flies from Manchester to New York’s JFK from £399. Premium fares from £629. thomascookairlines.com
